# **Fourier Series Reconstruction, Spectrum Analysis, and Autocorrelation of a Rectangular Prototype Signal**

In this workshop, we analyze a rectangular prototype signal using its trigonometric Fourier series. We reconstruct the signal using a finite number of harmonics (5 and 10), visualize the resulting approximations, and study their frequency spectra. Finally, we compute and interpret the autocorrelation of the reconstructed signal both numerically and analytically.

### **Non-Periodic Rectangular Pulse**

The non-periodic rectangular pulse is a single pulse of width $( \tau )$, centered at $( t = 0 )$, amplitude $(A)$, is defined as:

$
x(t) =
\begin{cases}
A, & \text{if } -\frac{\tau}{2} \le t \le \frac{\tau}{2} \\
0, & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}
$

![image.png](data:image/png;base64,)

## **Signal Reconstruction from Harmonic Components**

The rectangular signal $x(t)$ is reconstructed using a finite number of harmonics obtained from its trigonometric Fourier series representation

To approximate an aperiodic rectangular pulse, the signal is modeled as periodic with a large period. In this case, a period of $( T_0 = 10\tau $) is used to simulate the behavior of a single pulse using Fourier series techniques.


$x_N(t) = a_0 + \sum_{n=1}^{N} a_n \cos(n\omega_0 t) + b_n \sin(n\omega_0 t)$

Where:
- $( a_0 )$: DC (average) component
- $( a_n )$: Amplitude of the cosine wave with frequency $n\omega_0$
- $( b_n )$: Amplitude of the sine wave with frequency $n\omega_0$
- $( \omega_0 = \dfrac{2\pi}{T_0} $): Fundamental angular frequency

Calculating $\omega_0 = \frac{2\pi}{10\tau} = \frac{\pi}{5\tau}$

Calculating $a_0$

$a_0= \frac{1}{T_0}∫_{-\frac{T}{2}}^{\frac{T}{2}} x(t)dt$

However, since $x(t)= 0$ outside the pulse (when $|t| > \frac{\tau}{2}$), the function contributes **nothing** to the integral  in those regions. The rectangular signal is only **non-zero** between $-\frac{\tau}{2}$ and $\frac{\tau}{2}$, so the integral simplifies to:

$a_0= \frac{1}{10\tau}∫_{-\frac{\tau}{2}}^{\frac{\tau}{2}} Adt = \frac{1}{10\tau}A[t] _{-\frac{\tau}{2}}^{\frac{\tau}{2}}$

$a_0= \frac{1}{10\tau} A[\frac{\tau}{2} - (-\frac{\tau}{2})] = \frac{1}{10\tau} A\tau$

$a_0= \frac{A}{10}$

Calculating $a_n$

$a_n= \frac{2}{T_0}∫_{-∞}^{∞} x(t)dt$
